newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenia govt institute sees 1996 GDP up 3.1 pct.
newsitem.headline: Slovenia govt institute sees 1996 GDP up 3.1 pct.

text.p: Slovenia's state Institute of Macroeconomic Analysis said on Friday the country's gross domestic product for 1996 would rise by between 2.9 and 3.1 percent, at the lower end of the government's own forecast.
"The latest figures show GDP growth will not be far from three percent, possibly a 10th of a point more or less," the institute's senior analyst Dusan Kidric told Reuters.
He said industrial production, agricultural and construction figures all showed signs of growth.
Prime Minister Janez Drnovsek, who faces a general election on Sunday, has said he expects GDP in 1996 to grow by between three and four percent.
Drnvosek on Thursday pledged that Slovenian growth would rise by between four and five percent each of the next four years, should his government be returned to power.
"These growth figures are realistic...providing that our expectations of rising domestic and foreign investment after the privatisation process ends (in 1997) come true," Kidric said.
GDP growth in 1995 was 3.5 percent, down from 4.9 percent in 1994. - Marja Novak, Ljubljana newsroom, +386-61 125-8438
